cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Equip and adjust your motorcycle to carry the passenger.
questions.answerB: Ride as you would without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Ensure that footrests are available for only you, the operator.
questions.answerD: Instruct the passenger after you begin your trip.
questions.explanation: You should transport a passenger only if your motorcycle is appropriately equipped and adjusted to do so. Among other things, your motorcycle should have separate footrests for the passenger and a seat that is large enough for more than one person to sit comfortably. You may need to adjust your headlight, tire pressure, and suspension to accommodate the extra weight of a passenger.

questions.question: For routine braking:
questions.answerA: You should only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: You should only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: You should alternate between the front and rear brakes to maximize the life of the brakes.
questions.answerD: You should always use both the front and rear brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes every time that you slow or stop.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: When riding in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Use no lights.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the low and high beams.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in foggy conditions. Do not use your high beams when riding near other vehicles.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Lean as the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Requires a lot of traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should not rely on their mirrors to see whatâ€™s going on around them because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle mirrors are smaller than the mirrors on other vehicles, so you can't see as much.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles, like cars, have blind spots.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are never accurate.
questions.answerD: Mirrors take your eyes off the road in front of you and they should not be used.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles, like any other vehicle, have blind spots. Therefore, you cannot rely only on your mirrors to know what is happening behind you. Frequent head checks should be part of your normal routine.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerA: Wearing proper clothing
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: The front brake can provide how much of a motorcycle's braking power?
questions.answerA: 10 percent
questions.answerC: 50 percent
questions.answerD: 75 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: If a rider in a group wants to ride faster than the others, what should the group do?
questions.answerA: Let the rider go ahead and meet up at a designated spot later.
questions.answerB: Speed up to accommodate the one rider.
questions.answerC: Split up and have every rider travel as fast or as slow as they want.
questions.answerD: Let the rider that wants to go faster lead the group.
questions.explanation: If one member of a group wants to ride faster than the others, it is best to let them go ahead of the group and meet at a designated spot later.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: If road conditions require a longer stopping distance than normal, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your usual following distance.
questions.answerC: Travel on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Ask someone else to operate your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum three-second following distance.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: The center portion of a traffic lane is where:
questions.answerA: Debris and oil drippings from cars often collect.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle riders should always travel for safety.
questions.answerC: Most accidents happen.
questions.answerD: Drivers are least likely to see a motorcyclist.
questions.explanation: The centermost portion of a lane is where debris and oil drippings from cars often collect. Other hazards, such as utility hole covers, can also be found in the centermost portion of the lane.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerC: Does not have a chin strap.
questions.answerD: Protects the wearer's hearing.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have operated the involved motorcycle for less than six months.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders with less than six months of experience on the motorcycle being used.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster to shake them.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces does not provide poor traction?
questions.answerA: Wet pavement
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Snow
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; and painted lane markings can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: To be effective, eye or face shield protection must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerB: Too tight to allow sunglasses or eyeglasses to be worn.
questions.answerC: Free of scratches.
questions.answerD: Able to allow clear views to both sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: A danger of riding next to a row of parked cars is:
questions.answerA: You may not find a parking spot.
questions.answerB: A driver may unexpectedly pull out from the row into your path.
questions.answerC: Others may be driving slowly while looking for a parking spot.
questions.answerD: The road may be uneven.
questions.explanation: Riding next to parked cars presents a number of potential dangers. A driver might pull out of parking space and into your path without looking. Car doors may be opened into your lane and pedestrians may step out from between cars.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: When riding in a lane of traffic, a motorcycle operator:
questions.answerA: Should always ride in the same part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Should vary their lane position according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Should always ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerD: Should always ride in the left part of the lane.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: The gear shift lever is located:
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest.
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest.
questions.answerC: Behind the left footrest.
questions.answerD: Behind the right footrest.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the left foot. To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift. To downshift, press the shift lever down.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate out of the wobble.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: If you lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Release and re-apply the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep it locked until you completely stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and use both brakes to stop.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. You should still be able to steer your motorcycle with a locked rear wheel.

questions.question: Goggles can:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes and your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protect your eyes, but not your face.
questions.answerD: Not protect your face or eyes.
questions.explanation: Goggles can protect your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face in a crash.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerA: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: 100 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerA: Downshifting.
questions.answerC: Cross-shifting.
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: Means that they see you.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster than usual.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: A face shield:
questions.answerA: Provides protection for the eyes and face.
questions.answerC: Is required.
questions.answerD: Does not protect the face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, impact-resistant face shield provides the greatest degree of protection for a wearer's eyes and face. Eyeglasses or sunglasses are not an adequate substitute. In Vermont, you are not legally required to wear eye or face protection if your motorcycle has a windshield, though it is recommended.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicleâ€™s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Avoid other drivers' blindspots.
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: If you find your motorcycle being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Ride alongside the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When entering a highway or curve, motorcyclists riding in a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride single-file.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: While a staggered group formation is usually best, it is better to switch to a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: At high speeds.
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: When going through a turn on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your eyes focused close to the front of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Look through the turn to where you want to go.
questions.answerC: Turn your entire body to see through the turn.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed before the turn.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before a rider may begin to feel the effects?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerC: Six
questions.answerD: More than eight
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can affect a person's ability to ride. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Which portion of the lane should be avoided?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: No portion of the lane should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for riding conditions.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Ride faster than you usually would.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your high beam headlight.
questions.explanation: Because distances are more difficult to judge in the dark than in daylight, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance when riding at night. Use your high beam any time you are not meeting or following another vehicle.

questions.question: If your friend has been drinking alcohol, it is a good idea to do any of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Arrange for a safe ride home for your friend.
questions.answerB: Occupy your friend with activities to distract them from drinking.
questions.answerC: Keep your friend from leaving until they are sober.
questions.answerD: Allow your friend to ride their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from riding their motorcycle while impaired. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.

questions.question: When making an ordinary stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake to save the front brake for special situations.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake to save the rear brake for special situations.
questions.answerD: Sharply squeeze the front brake only.
questions.explanation: Develop the habit of using both brakes every time you slow or stop. If you need to stop quickly, it is best to apply both brakes. It will be easier to apply both brakes in a quick stop if you have already developed this habit.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerA: Brakes.
questions.answerC: Suspension.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: When checking tire pressure:
questions.answerA: Eyeballing the tire is a good method.
questions.answerC: It is best to squeeze the tire.
questions.answerD: Compare the height of the tire to another tire.
questions.explanation: You should use a tire gauge to check the tire pressure before every ride. An under-inflated tire may still look okay, so a visual check is not enough.

questions.question: Convex mirrors make cars seem:
questions.answerA: Larger.
questions.answerC: Faster.
questions.answerD: Narrower.
questions.explanation: Rounded, or convex, mirrors provide a wider view of the road than flat mirrors, but they also make objects seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: What is the primary psychoactive component in marijuana?
questions.answerA: THC
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Ride while using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: It is a good idea to drag your feet.
questions.answerB: Your toes should be pointed downward.
questions.answerC: You should keep your feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: You should try to keep your feet away from the controls.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper balance, your feet should be placed firmly on the footrests and not dragged on the ground. Do not point your toes downward, as this may cause them to catch on the road. Keep your feet near the controls so you can reach them quickly, if needed.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: To be seen in the rearview mirror of the driver ahead of you, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: If you are following a car, the driver is most likely to notice you if you position yourself behind them in the center of your lane. This lane position places you in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: There is no need to do a head check if you use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Mirrors provide a full view of the road around your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should turn your head and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: You can assume drivers will properly respond to your turn signal.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: An adequate cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to react if another driver makes a mistake.
questions.answerB: Keeps you in a single area of the lane, limiting your movement.
questions.answerC: Allows you to rely on others to identify hazards.
questions.answerD: Requires you go faster to stay with traffic.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space on all sides of your motorcycle helps to ensure that you have time and space to react if another road user makes a mistake.

questions.question: What should a motorcyclist do to prevent possible injury when riding on a slippery surface?
questions.answerA: Increase their speed.
questions.answerC: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When riding on a slippery surface, it is safest to decrease your speed. Making sudden moves on a slippery surface could cause your motorcycle to skid. Do not travel on the shoulder to escape a slippery road.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must start and complete the pass within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: You should sound your horn to get the other driver to slow down.
questions.explanation: All passing maneuvers must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Involve riders who have operated their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.answerB: Are caused by faulty ignition systems.
questions.answerC: Occur because of distractions caused by passengers.
questions.answerD: Happen at night.
questions.explanation: Always be very careful when riding a motorcycle that is new to you. In most motorcycle crashes, the operator had less than six months of experience on the bike that they were riding.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: You should do a pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: A small technical fault can have much more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. To avoid these consequences, inspect your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the front brake.
questions.answerB: Rely only on the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake and then the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, you should apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders behind them to keep an eye on them.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerA: Heightened riding abilities.
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best riding formation is generally:
questions.answerA: Pairs.
questions.answerC: A single-file line.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally best when riding in a group. You should move into a single-file line when turning, riding in a curve, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerA: Engine braking.
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerA: Should be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: Small vehicles can appear ______ and seem to be traveling ______ than they actually are.
questions.answerA: Farther away, more slowly
questions.answerC: Closer, more slowly
questions.answerD: Closer, faster
questions.explanation: Small vehicles, like motorcycles, can visually seem to be farther away and moving more slowly than they actually are. This phenomenon can make it difficult for others on the road to accurately judge the location and speed of a smaller vehicle.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: Of the following, which should you not do to improve your safety when riding at night?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlight whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: To ride safely at night, you should reduce your speed, use your high beam headlight when you are not riding near other vehicles, and increase your following distance. Take advantage of vehicles ahead of you to provide clues about the upcoming road. Their headlights may help to illuminate the road ahead and their taillights will bounce up and down if the vehicle is being driven over bumps on the road.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: To lean a motorcycle when making a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Always press on the left handgrip.
questions.answerB: Always press on the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press on the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To turn, a motorcycle must lean. To make the motorcycle lean, press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Using both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using both the front and rear brakes while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: On a straightaway, you can stop in the shortest distance by using both brakes. Try to avoid locking either brake.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerA: Should always stay the same.
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerA: Your right hand.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: It is recommended that a motorcyclist:
questions.answerA: Shift gears in a turn.
questions.answerC: Change power suddenly in a turn.
questions.answerD: Ride the brake throughout the turn.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you change gears prior to entering a turn.

questions.question: To swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended direction of escape. To swerve to the left, press the left handgrip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handgrip, then the left.

questions.question: When riding, goggles:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Are not as effective at protecting your eyes as eyeglasses.
questions.answerD: Are not effective in providing any protection.
questions.explanation: Goggles can provide protection for your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face. Eyeglasses are not an adequate substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerA: May be increased.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Adjust the shocks.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: When riding in traffic, it is important to remember that motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots that are too small to cause any problems.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that require head checks.
questions.answerD: Have only one blind spot.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, motorcycles have blind spots. Always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerA: Time.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerA: Read books about carrying passengers.
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: The effects of marijuana consumption can last for:
questions.answerA: No more than 15 minutes.
questions.answerC: About two hours.
questions.answerD: More than six hours.
questions.explanation: When marijuana is smoked, it can begin to affect the smoker within minutes and effects can last for between two and four hours. When marijuana is eaten, it may take over an hour to begin to affect the consumer, but the effects of the marijuana may last for more than six hours.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger in a sidecar, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin slowing sooner than usual.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes more firmly than usual to stop quickly.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes more softly than usual to keep from overworking them.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger in a sidecar will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to require extra space to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: The left position in the lane
questions.answerB: The center position in the lane
questions.answerC: The right position in the lane
questions.answerD: There is no single lane position that is best for all situations.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for your current riding conditions, allowing you to maintain an adequate space cushion and be visible to others.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid traffic signals.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: Where is the front brake lever usually located?
questions.answerA: On the left handgrip
questions.answerC: By the left foot peg
questions.answerD: By the right foot peg
questions.explanation: The front brake lever is generally located on the right handgrip. Make sure that you are aware of the locations of all your motorcycle's controls before beginning to ride.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerA: Helps you to be seen.
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: When you are being passed by a vehicle on your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Help the other driver by moving as far to the right as possible.
questions.answerB: Help the other driver by moving to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the left portion of your lane
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous because it may tempt them to merge back into your lane too soon. Stay in the center portion of the lane when being passed.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerA: Far from home.
questions.answerC: On long rides.
questions.answerD: Several hours into the ride.
questions.explanation: Most crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: If you think stopping your motorcycle will take longer than usual, you should:
questions.answerA: Lengthen your following distance.
questions.answerC: Leave the road.
questions.answerD: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Lengthen your following distance when traveling on a slippery surface. If it will take longer than usual for your motorcycle to stop, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should continually scan the road ahead for:
questions.answerA: Road conditions.
questions.answerC: Escape routes.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Scan the road ahead to remain alert to changing traffic conditions, hazardous road conditions, and escape routes. Be prepared to react to any changing conditions.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the portion of the lane that will bring you into other drivers' fields of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Always be in the left lane to be the farthest from oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Slowly sneak up to the intersection.
questions.answerD: Weave slightly in your lane so your headlight has a better chance of being spotted.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the part of the lane that will bring you into an oncoming driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment. For example, when approaching a blind corner to your right, you may be seen sooner if you are in the left portion of your lane and not in the center portion.

questions.question: When riding in a group, motorcyclists:
questions.answerA: Do not need space cushions.
questions.answerC: Should reduce their usual space cushions by half.
questions.answerD: Should maintain adequate space cushions.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, you should maintain close ranks but still keep an adequate space cushion around each rider.

questions.question: When riding in a group, it is best to put inexperienced riders near the front because:
questions.answerA: Experienced riders can more easily keep an eye on them.
questions.answerB: They will get lost if they are leading.
questions.answerC: They may slow the group down as the leaders.
questions.answerD: They will ride too fast in any other position.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should ride toward the front, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can easily watch them.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerA: On the right handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerA: The ownerâ€™s manual.
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driverâ€™s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: The proper footwear for riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Has long, loose laces.
questions.answerC: Has tall heels.
questions.answerD: Is always sneakers.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should wear sturdy footwear that is high enough to cover and support your ankles. Short-heeled footwear is best because taller heels may catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so that they can't be caught on anything.

questions.question: Riding between two vehicles moving in the same direction:
questions.answerA: Is illegal.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged if traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged during the day to prevent traffic jams.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if the motorcyclist is comfortable with the move.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is illegal for motorcycles and mopeds to pass between two moving vehicles on a multilane highway or one-way street.

questions.question: Helmeted riders are ________ more likely to survive than those not wearing helmets at the time of a crash.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerC: Eight times
questions.answerD: Ten times
questions.explanation: At any speed, wearing a helmet will make you three times more likely to survive head injuries in the event of a crash than you would if not wearing a helmet.

questions.question: Common drugs, such as cold tablets:
questions.answerA: Can affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Usually wonâ€™t affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Pose no risk to a rider's operating abilities.
questions.answerD: Are always acceptable to take before riding because they are sold over-the-counter.
questions.explanation: Almost all drugs, including over-the-counter medications, have the potential to impact the abilities you need to ride safely. Make sure you understand the side effects of any drug before combining it with riding.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When youâ€™re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerA: In pairs.
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: Of the following, which clothing item will not reduce injuries in a crash?
questions.answerA: Heavy shoes
questions.answerC: Shorts
questions.answerD: Full-fingered gloves
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of injury, riders should wear a helmet, eye protection, heavy shoes or boots, full-length pants, a jacket, and full-fingered gloves. Clothing should be made of durable materials to best protect the wearer.

questions.question: When riding under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least four seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: If you are riding when it starts to rain, it is a good idea to:
questions.answerA: Ride down the center of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Pull onto the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: Because of the presence of oil deposits, the center strip of a lane can be hazardous when wet. When rain starts to fall, it is best to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. It is advisable to reduce your speed on wet surfaces.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe step in preventing fatigue while riding?
questions.answerA: Protecting yourself from the elements
questions.answerC: Limiting the distance ridden in one day
questions.answerD: Taking frequent breaks
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest and try not to ride more than six hours in one day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements. Avoid taking artificial stimulants, as the effects when they wear off can be very dangerous.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: When entering a turn, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Move their shoulders to match the angle of the turn.
questions.answerD: Sit up as high as possible.
questions.explanation: Before entering a turn, a motorcyclist should reduce their speed by closing the throttle and, if necessary, applying both brakes.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
