questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerA: As low as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: Riding gloves should:
questions.answerA: Not be worn because they will make your hands too hot.
questions.answerB: Be worn to provide a better grip on the handgrips.
questions.answerC: Not be worn because they will make it more difficult to work the controls.
questions.answerD: Be worn only on cooler days.
questions.explanation: Gloves made of leather, or another durable material, should be worn when riding. They will provide you with an improved grip on the handgrips, as well as help protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can improve their visibility by:
questions.answerA: Wearing darkly-colored clothing.
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle very closely.
questions.answerD: Wearing brightly-colored clothing.
questions.explanation: To maximize your chances of being seen by other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Can place you in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerB: Is better than riding behind the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is safe because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerD: Should only be done during the day.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding directly alongside another vehicle, since this may place you in the vehicle's blind spot. If the driver can't see you, they may enter your lane without warning. Riding alongside a vehicle is also dangerous because the vehicle will block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerA: Stopping frequently.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: In a normal turn:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean together.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should lean, but the rider should not.
questions.answerD: The rider should lean, but the motorcycle should not.
questions.explanation: During normal turns, the motorcycle and the rider should be leaning together at the same angle. In slow, tight turns, only the motorcycle should lean while the rider keeps their body straight up.

questions.question: Shifting into a lower gear causes an effect similar to:
questions.answerA: Using the brakes.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Shifting your motorcycle into a lower gear causes an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: Use your mirrors when stopped at an intersection:
questions.answerA: To see if vehicles parked on the sides of the street are entering traffic.
questions.answerB: To look for vehicles changing lanes.
questions.answerC: To watch for vehicles behind you that may not be slowing down.
questions.answerD: To see if someone is planning to turn behind you.
questions.explanation: When you are stopped at an intersection, use your mirrors to check for cars approaching you from behind. The drivers may not notice you until they are too close and you may need to react.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must start and complete the pass within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: You should sound your horn to get the other driver to slow down.
questions.explanation: All passing maneuvers must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: More than half of all motorcycle crashes:
questions.answerA: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Occur at speeds above 55 mph.
questions.answerD: Involve inexperienced riders.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders who have been using their motorcycle for less than six months. Most crashes take place in broad daylight when the riders are traveling at low speeds.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of riding in a close group?
questions.answerA: It takes up minimal space on the highway.
questions.answerB: The group is easy to see.
questions.answerC: The group is unlikely to be split up.
questions.answerD: The riders will get to their destination more quickly in a close group than a group that is spread out.
questions.explanation: Riding in close ranks is recommended over riding in a group that is spread out because the group will take up less space on the road, be easier for others to see, and be less likely to get separated at traffic lights and during passes.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Allow you to set up for turns.
questions.answerC: Allow you to avoid wind blasts from other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Allow you to be in another vehicleâ€™s blind spot.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Dress warmly.
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: If a driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Prevent them from passing.
questions.answerD: Move to one side of your lane to allow them to share the lane.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to keep tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using the front brake, then the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Using the rear brake, then the front brake.
questions.answerC: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by simultaneously applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: Youâ€™ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A DOT-approved helmet.
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When choosing a lane position, you should consider:
questions.answerA: Whether or not other drivers will see you.
questions.answerB: How many cars are on the road ahead.
questions.answerC: Which portion of the lane will result in a shorter trip.
questions.answerD: If you can pass more vehicles in a certain position than in another.
questions.explanation: While a properly chosen lane position can offer several advantages, you should be certain that your lane position will allow you to be seen by others and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: The front brake can provide how much of a motorcycle's braking power?
questions.answerA: 10 percent
questions.answerC: 50 percent
questions.answerD: 75 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: When it is obvious that you are going to turn, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.answerB: Should still use a turn signal.
questions.answerC: Only need to use a turn signal if there are nearby pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Only need to use a turn signal if you are at a stop light.
questions.explanation: You must use proper turn signals every time you turn or change lanes, even if you think your intentions are obvious. Signals are always important, even if no one else seems to be around to see them. There may be other vehicles nearby that you can't see or haven't yet noticed.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: The effects of marijuana consumption can last for:
questions.answerA: No more than 15 minutes.
questions.answerC: About two hours.
questions.answerD: More than six hours.
questions.explanation: When marijuana is smoked, it can begin to affect the smoker within minutes and effects can last for between two and four hours. When marijuana is eaten, it may take over an hour to begin to affect the consumer, but the effects of the marijuana may last for more than six hours.

questions.question: To provide the best protection, a helmet should:
questions.answerA: Have a few cracks.
questions.answerC: Have frayed straps.
questions.answerD: Fit snugly.
questions.explanation: To ensure you are getting the best protection, you should choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and have no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerA: Should always stay the same.
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerD: Welcome other drivers into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehiclesâ€™ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: An adequate cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to react if another driver makes a mistake.
questions.answerB: Keeps you in a single area of the lane, limiting your movement.
questions.answerC: Allows you to rely on others to identify hazards.
questions.answerD: Requires you go faster to stay with traffic.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space on all sides of your motorcycle helps to ensure that you have time and space to react if another road user makes a mistake.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep riding, as the wobble will likely correct itself.
questions.answerC: Close the throttle to slow down.
questions.answerD: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble will only increase the problem. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down while gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as you can, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Once off the road, you should address the problem causing the wobble.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Not worry about them.
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Studies show that when motorcycles have their headlights turned on during the day:
questions.answerA: They are not as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They are more visible to other drivers than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.answerC: Other drivers are often confused.
questions.answerD: They are less safe than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.explanation: The best way to help other drivers see your motorcycle is to keep your headlight on whenever you ride. During the day, a motorcycle with its headlight on is twice as likely to be noticed.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerA: Fits loosely.
questions.answerC: Has survived a previous crash.
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerA: Lean as you lean.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: When riding, goggles:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Are not as effective at protecting your eyes as eyeglasses.
questions.answerD: Are not effective in providing any protection.
questions.explanation: Goggles can provide protection for your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face. Eyeglasses are not an adequate substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: When following another vehicle as a beginning rider, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain a minimum four-second following distance.
questions.answerB: Get as close to the other vehicle as possible.
questions.answerC: Never be concerned about your following distance.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the left portion of the lane so the driver can easily see you.
questions.explanation: A following distance of at least four seconds is recommended for beginning riders. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: During the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Not ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerB: Ride with your headlight on, but only if it is cloudy.
questions.answerC: Always ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerD: Use your headlight if you think it helps.
questions.explanation: You should always have your headlight on when riding, even during the day. This can make you twice as likely to be noticed by other drivers.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should choose footwear with soles that:
questions.answerA: Are made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.
questions.answerC: Have tall heels.
questions.answerD: Are made of soft, flimsy material.
questions.explanation: Choose riding boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Choose footwear with soles made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: When making an ordinary stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake to save the front brake for special situations.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake to save the rear brake for special situations.
questions.answerD: Sharply squeeze the front brake only.
questions.explanation: Develop the habit of using both brakes every time you slow or stop. If you need to stop quickly, it is best to apply both brakes. It will be easier to apply both brakes in a quick stop if you have already developed this habit.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: When riding under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least four seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces does not provide poor traction?
questions.answerA: Wet pavement
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Snow
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; and painted lane markings can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to get onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side of the lane nearest the passing driver increases the danger of a collision, and riding on the side farthest from the passing driver may tempt them to return to your lane too soon.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: In the state of Kentucky, a person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerA: Warning
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When roads are slippery.
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid traffic signals.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle's former owner.
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Avoid other road users' blind spots.
questions.answerB: Provide a good view of the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Provide a poor view of road hazards.
questions.answerD: Invite others to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should help you to see others and be seen by them. Avoid riding in another driver's blind spot for a long period of time.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Passing another vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: If you wait one hour to ride after having one alcoholic drink:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and driving.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected by the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Effects from the alcohol may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: When packing a load on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The heavier items should go toward the front.
questions.answerB: The heavier items should go toward the rear.
questions.answerC: Mounting loads behind the rear axle is recommended.
questions.answerD: Lighter items should be stored in front of you.
questions.explanation: Loads should be positioned forward with heavier items toward the front of the load. Loads should be over or in front of the rear axle. Lighter items should be packed behind you.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should travel:
questions.answerA: More slowly than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerB: At the speed you would travel during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerC: Faster than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road so other vehicles can see you.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, travel at a slower speed than you would during the day under similar weather and traffic conditions. It can be difficult to see potential hazards in the dark, so slowing down can increase your chances of avoiding any hazards.
